title: 2. How to search for and fetch sequences
text: Let’s pretend ’re interested COI sequences group rodents called Sciuromorpha. restez provides ncbi_acc_get() function make easy: just provide text string query like NCBI GenBank, returns character vector accession numbers corresponding query. default, drops version number accession number. strictly necessary, makes easier check results restez later.
code: library(restez)  # 33553 - Sciuromorpha - squirrel-like things accessions <- ncbi_acc_get(   'txid33553[Organism:exp] AND COI [GENE] AND 100:1000[SLEN]') print(length(accessions)) #> [1] 492 print(accessions[1:10]) #>  [1] "MZ661159" "MZ364430" "HQ966965" "GU670702" "GU670701" "GU670700" "GU670699" "GU670462" "GU670451" "GU670450"

title: 2. How to search for and fetch sequences
text: fetch sequences rodents database, can use gb_fasta_get function.
code: restez_path_set(rodents_path) coi_sequences <- gb_fasta_get(id = accessions) str(coi_sequences[[1]]) #>  chr ">LT630607.1 Sciurus sp. 1 AG-2016 mitochondrial partial COI gene for cytochrome oxidase subunit 1, specimen vou"| __truncated__ # Are all accessions in results? all(accessions %in% names(coi_sequences)) #> [1] TRUE

title: 2. How to search for and fetch sequences
text: Can just use rentrez fetching well? Yes, restez can lot faster. NCBI limits number requests per user, often little 100 items per request varying time delays. Additionally programmatic retrieval sequences using online server can never reliable local copy.
code: # time via restez system.time(expr = {   coi_sequences <- gb_fasta_get(id = accessions)   }) #>    user  system elapsed  #>   0.259   0.077   0.272 # time via Entrez system.time(expr = {   coi_sequences_p1 <- rentrez::entrez_fetch(db = 'nucleotide',                                             id = accessions[1:100],                                             rettype = 'fasta')   coi_sequences_p2 <- rentrez::entrez_fetch(db = 'nucleotide',                                             id = accessions[101:200],                                             rettype = 'fasta')   coi_sequences_p3 <- rentrez::entrez_fetch(db = 'nucleotide',                                             id = accessions[201:300],                                             rettype = 'fasta')   coi_sequences_p4 <- rentrez::entrez_fetch(db = 'nucleotide',                                             id = accessions[301:400],                                             rettype = 'fasta')   coi_sequences_p5 <- rentrez::entrez_fetch(db = 'nucleotide',                                             id = accessions[401:456],                                             rettype = 'fasta')   }) #>    user  system elapsed  #>   0.050   0.008   5.536

title: 3. Advanced parsing of a GenBank record
text: can extract different elements record gb_extract() ….
code: # such as the LOCUS information ... (gb_extract(record = record, what = 'locus')) #>     accession        length           mol          type        domain          date  #>    "AY952423"        "2623"         "DNA"      "linear"         "PLN" "17-APR-2005" # the accession (gb_extract(record = record, what = 'accession')) #> [1] "AY952423" # the accession + version (gb_extract(record = record, what = 'version')) #> [1] "AY952423.1" # the organism name (gb_extract(record = record, what = 'organism')) #> [1] "Livistona chinensis" # the sequence definition line (gb_extract(record = record, what = 'definition')) #> [1] "Livistona chinensis tRNA-Lys (trnK) gene, partial sequence; and matK gene, complete sequence; chloroplast" # the keywords (this record doesn't have any ....) (gb_extract(record = record, what = 'keywords')) #> [1] "" # even the features as a list object features <- gb_extract(record = record, what = 'features') print(features[[1]]) #> $type #> [1] "source" #>  #> $location #> [1] "1..2623" #>  #> $organism #> [1] "Livistona chinensis" #>  #> $organelle #> [1] "plastid:chloroplast" #>  #> $mol_type #> [1] "genomic DNA" #>  #> $db_xref #> [1] "taxon:115492gene            <1..>2623" #>  #> $gene #> [1] "trnK" #>  #> $note #> [1] "tRNA-Lysintron          <1..>2623" # and of course the sequence itself seq <- gb_extract(record = record, what = 'sequence') str(seq) #>  chr "ATTGGGGTTGCTAACTCAACGGTAGAGTACTCGGCTTTTAAGTGCGACTATCATCTTTTACACATTTGGATGAAGTAAGGAATTCGTCCAGACTATTGGTAGAGTCTATAA"| __truncated__

title: 4. Running phylotaR with restez
text: Sequences found locally downloaded via Entrez. Sequences may found locally three sets reasons, 1. phylotaR may identified non-GenBank sequences (e.g. RefSeq), 2. local database may size limits (min 100 max 1000), 3. local database date, new GenBank releases made month. Note: phylotaR messages explicit state using restez database, , may set restez path. Compared running without restez database, phylotaR download can run 2x faster.

title: 5. Tips and Tricks
text: advisable download entire GenBank database machine. Equally, best limit size database. Databases large slow query likely cause memory issues. example, may actually make query demands memory available machine. One solution instead set multiple restez paths machine. can either set path different domains. download single set domains create database downloaded files using alt_restez_path argument.
code: # a larger database from the same download files in rodents_path db_create(alt_restez_path = rodents_path, max_length = 2000)

title: 5. Tips and Tricks
text: Another way create smaller (.e., efficient) databases use accession filter. particularly useful organisms interested small subset much larger domain. example, might interested ferns, since ferns part plant domain (smallest domain including ferns plants), means need download entire plant domain (638 GB release 251!). restez download just ferns, can build database including ferns, much efficient querying database plants. , use ncbi_acc_get() first obtain vector accessions (GenBank IDs). Construct query searching GenBank. Next, use vector accessions accession filter (acc_filter) db_create(). One tip: use scan speed process building database. Particularly cases target sequences (, ferns) small part GenBank domain (, plants), many GenBank files contain target sequences . Setting scan TRUE first check target accessions present file , skip processing file . can significantly save time available machines zgrep installed (typically Mac Unix, Windows).
code: # Specify vector of GenBank accessions: # all ferns in GenBank between with sequence length between 10 to 200000 bases fern_accs <- ncbi_acc_get("Polypodiopsida[ORGN] AND 10:200000[SLEN]") db_create(acc_filter = fern_accs, scan = TRUE)

title: Create and Query a Local Copy of GenBank in R
text: can download anything, need tell restez like store downloaded files eventual GenBank database. use restez_path_set() function. function user can provide system file path folder within function create new folder called ‘restez’. example, create restez folder temporary folder. user must always set restez path order use restez library. Additionally, running restez_path_set() new folder messages printed console telling us path created downloads subfolder created. Note, whenever intend use restez need specify restez path. using regularly, might good idea set using .Rprofile. restez_path_set() needs run per R session, use repeatedly chunks just reminder.
code: # set a random number generator seed for reproducibility set.seed(12345)  library(restez) # rstz_pth <- tempdir() restez_path_set(filepath = rstz_pth) #> ... Creating '/tmp/RtmpA3Wsd0/restez' #> ... Creating '/tmp/RtmpA3Wsd0/restez/downloads'

title: Create and Query a Local Copy of GenBank in R
text: Now can download GenBank files using db_download(). interactive function looks latest GenBank release, parses release notes, prints console available sets flatfiles can downloaded. example, select smallest available domain ‘Unannotated’ can pre-specified ‘20’. Note numbering scheme may change GenBank releases, shouldn’t assume given number correspond domain run later. Instead, can run function without preselection argument wait function prompt domain selection, show current numbering scheme. launching, download function ask whether OK download set database selected sequence files. selection likely large can always quit process using either Esc Ctrl+c. Please note diskspace estimates preliminary. package tries conservative estimates. Now download begun, just need wait finish. largest domains, can take quite may prone server errors. case, may want set max_tries argument db_download() relatively high number automatically re-try downloading number tries exceeded (case, sure set overwrite FALSE download start scratch).

title: Create and Query a Local Copy of GenBank in R
text: restez database set can query database using gb_*_get() functions. functions allow us retrieve specific columns SQL-like database: ‘sequence’, ‘definition’, ‘accession’, ‘version’ ‘organism’. Also, allow us get whole text formatted record sequence data fasta format. example, can use list_db_ids() identify accession numbers database. also use entrez_search() provided database contains sequences interest us, see ‘search fetch’. Additionally, flexibility options extracting sequence record information see GenBank record parsing.

title: Create and Query a Local Copy of GenBank in R
text: NOTE: Starting v2.0.0, database backend changed MonetDBLite duckdb. change, restez v2.0.0 higher compatible databases built previous versions restez. Download parts NCBI’s GenBank local folder create simple SQL-like database. Use ‘get’ tools query database accession IDs. rentrez wrappers available, sequences available locally can searched online Entrez. See detailed tutorials information.

title: Create and Query a Local Copy of GenBank in R
text: Vous entrez, vous rentrez et, maintenant, vous …. restez! Downloading sequences sequence information GenBank related NCBI taxonomic databases often performed via NCBI API, Entrez. Entrez, however, limit number requests downloading large amounts sequence data way can inefficient. programmatic situations multiple Entrez calls made, downloading may take days, weeks even months. package aims make sequence retrieval efficient allowing user download large sections GenBank database local machine query local database either package specific functions Entrez wrappers. process efficient GenBank downloads made via NCBI’s FTP using compressed sequence files. good internet connection middle---road computer, database comprising 20 GB sequence information can generated less 10 minutes.

title: Create new NCBI database — db_create
text: Create new local SQL database downloaded files. Currently GenBank/nucleotide/nuccore database supported.

title: Create new NCBI database — db_create
code: db_create(   db_type = "nucleotide",   min_length = 0,   max_length = NULL,   acc_filter = NULL,   invert = FALSE,   alt_restez_path = NULL,   scan = FALSE )

title: Create new NCBI database — db_create
text: db_type character, database type min_length Minimum sequence length, default 0. max_length Maximum sequence length, default NULL. acc_filter Character vector; accessions include exclude database specified invert. invert Logical vector length 1; TRUE, accessions acc_filter excluded database; FALSE, accessions acc_filter included database. Default FALSE. alt_restez_path Alternative restez path like use downloads different restez path. scan Logical vector length 1; sequence file scanned accessions acc_filter prior processing? Requires zgrep installed (work Windows). used acc_filter NULL invert FALSE. Default FALSE.

title: Create new NCBI database — db_create
text: .seq.gz files added database default. user can specify minimum/maximum sequence lengths accession numbers limit sequences added database -- smaller databases faster search. final selection sequences result applying filters (acc_filter, min_length, max_length) combination. scan option can decrease time needed build database small number sequences written database compared number sequences downloaded GenBank; .e., many files downloaded GenBank contain sequences written database. set TRUE, file contain accessions acc_filter, processing file skipped none sequences contains added database. Alternatively, user can use alt_restez_path add files alternative restez file path. example, may wish database environmental sequences additional smaller one just sequences lengths 100 bp. Instead download environmental sequences twice, can generate multiple restez databases using downloaded files single restez path. function overwrite pre-existing database. Old databases must deleted new one can created. Use db_delete() everything=FALSE delete SQL database. Connections/disconnections database made automatically.

title: Create new NCBI database — db_create
code: if (FALSE) { # Example of general usage library(restez) restez_path_set(filepath = 'path/for/downloads/and/database') db_download() db_create()  # Example of using `acc_filter` # # Download files to temporary directory temp_dir <- paste0(tempdir(), "/restez", collapse = "") dir.create(temp_dir) restez_path_set(filepath = temp_dir) # Choose GenBank domain 20 ('unannotated'), the smallest db_download(preselection = 20) # Only include three accessions in database db_create(   acc_filter = c("AF000122", "AF000123", "AF000124") ) list_db_ids() db_delete() unlink(temp_dir) }

code: library(restez) restez_path_set(tempdir()) #> ... Creating '/tmp/RtmpUhc9R4/restez' #> ... Creating '/tmp/RtmpUhc9R4/restez/downloads' demo_db_create(n = 5) # return fasta record fasta_res <- entrez_fetch(db = 'nucleotide',                           id = c('demo_1', 'demo_2'),                           rettype = 'fasta') cat(fasta_res) #> >demo_1.2 A demonstration sequence | id demo_1 #> ATTAACAGCG #>  #> >demo_2.2 A demonstration sequence | id demo_2 #> CCGGCAGAAA #>  # return whole GB record in text format gb_res <- entrez_fetch(db = 'nucleotide',                        id = c('demo_1', 'demo_2'),                        rettype = 'gb') cat(gb_res) #> LOCUS       [This is a mock GenBank data record] #> DEFINITION  A demonstration sequence | id demo_1 #> ACCESSION   demo_1 #> VERSION     2 #> KEYWORDS    [keyword] #> SOURCE      [tissue, organism] #> ORGANISM    Unreal organism 1 #> REFERENCE   [reference data] #> AUTHORS     [all the authors] #> TITLE       [title] #> JOURNAL     [journal] #> FEATURES    [features] #>  #> ORIGIN       #>         1 attaacagcg #>  #>  #> LOCUS       [This is a mock GenBank data record] #> DEFINITION  A demonstration sequence | id demo_2 #> ACCESSION   demo_2 #> VERSION     2 #> KEYWORDS    [keyword] #> SOURCE      [tissue, organism] #> ORGANISM    Unreal organism 2 #> REFERENCE   [reference data] #> AUTHORS     [all the authors] #> TITLE       [title] #> JOURNAL     [journal] #> FEATURES    [features] #>  #> ORIGIN       #>         1 ccggcagaaa #>  #>  # NOT RUN # whereas these request would go through rentrez # fasta_res <- entrez_fetch(db = 'nucleotide', #                           id = c('S71333', 'S71334'), #                           rettype = 'fasta') # gb_res <- entrez_fetch(db = 'nucleotide', #                        id = c('S71333', 'S71334'), #                        rettype = 'gb')  # delete demo after example db_delete(everything = TRUE)
